newsitem.title: DENMARK: More Danish firms setting up own risk operations.
newsitem.headline: More Danish firms setting up own risk operations.

text.p: Leading Danish firms, hoping to improve their risk management, are increasingly looking to set up their own in-house insurance operations, the Confederation of Danish Industries said on Friday.

"I think that we are going to see a growing interest among Danish firms in insuring themselves," Erik Larsen of the confederation's risk management section told the daily newspaper Berlingske Tidende.
"We know several big firms are seriously looking into the possibility. I predict a doubling in firms running their own risk operations within the next five to 10 years," he said.
He said that 10 major Danish firms had so far set up insurance operations. However, administering one's own risks would be viable only for large companies, he noted.
Larsen said the trend reflected increasing demand for more flexible, individual insurance services, tailor-made for individual needs.
Widespread mergers in recent years unsettled the Danish insurance industry and brought charges of falling service standards during the period of adjustment.
